abstracts.cdata!:
The audit concurs with the
            Implementation Completion Report (ICR) ratings of
            satisfactory project outcome, likely sustainability, and
            high institutional development impacts, in addition to the
            satisfactory performance ratings by both the Bank and
            Borrower. Lessons of experience include the following. In
            the absence of strong capacity, particularly in countries
            new to Bank lending, projects should include training in
            Bank procurement, and financial management in the
            implementation plan, prioritizing a limited number of
            components, emphasizing on monitoring and evaluation of
            implementation arrangements, and performance indicators. In
            addition, a number of lessons lend insight to OED's
            evaluation of the Bank's HIV/AIDS assistance:
            Investment in institutional development can have a dramatic
            impact on the ability of the Government to define, and lead
            the national AIDS agenda, while promoting government
            commitment to fight HIV/AIDS and support public health,
            requires continuing efforts. Cambodia's HIV/AIDS
            strategy focuses scarce capacity on preventing transmission
            among high-risk groups; instead, a big difference could be
            an HIV/AIDS program, that provide the foundation for
            multisectoral efforts to be built. In turn, building
            capacity of nongovernmental organizations is critical for
            resources mobilization, to help track HIV prevalence and
            behavior, and, monitor epidemic outcomes linked with inputs
            and outputs to establish plausible causality.
